description: a(n) = smallest k >= 2 such that k^(2^n)+1 is prime, or -1 if no such k exists.
comments: Smallest base value yielding generalized Fermat primes. - _Hugo Pfoertner_, Jul 01 2003The first 5 terms correspond with the known (ordinary) Fermat primes. A probable candidate for the next entry is 62722^131072+1, discovered by Michael Angel in 2003. It has 628808 decimal digits. - _Hugo Pfoertner_, Jul 01 2003For any n, a(n+1) >= sqrt(a(n)), because k^(2^(n+1))+1 = (k^2)^(2^n)+1. - _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Sep 16 2015Does the sequence contain any perfect squares? If a(n) is a perfect square, then a(n+1) = sqrt(a(n)). - _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Sep 16 2015If for a particular n, a(n) exists, then a(i) exist for all i=0,1,2,...,n. No proof is known that this sequence is infinite. Such a result would clearly imply the infinitude of A002496. - _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Sep 18 2015
links: Lucile and Yves Gallot, Generalized Fermat Prime Search!
mathematica: f[n_] := (p = 2^n; k = 2; While[cp = k^p + 1; !PrimeQ@cp, k++ ]; k); Do[ Print[{n, f@n}], {n, 0, 17}] (* _Lei Zhou_, Feb 21 2005 *)
